inventory/service/groups.yaml.message: Why does this file end up in inventory/service and not inventory/base like the openstack inventory does?

We need 2 sets of hostvars (We only have 1 in this patch) so we put the groups.yaml into one dir and the hosts.yaml into the other dir - ansible will pull hostvars from adjacency to both of them.

I figured groups are really associted more with the logical services and hosts themselves are more about the underlying nodes, so figured putting base hostvars with hosts and service hostvars with groups made sense.

networking_vpp/agent/server.py.message: Where is the specific keyerror happening? This is a large try/except block and I wonder if we can make it more specific.

It's definitely not happening at 2749, it seems, because remove_acls_on_port catches its own keyerror.  I can see it might happen at 2724, or perhaps in _set_acls_on_vpp_port within maybe_set_acls_on_port (which doesn't look that defensive and should be made more so).

OK, can we tightn up the try/except or push it into the functions in question?  It shouldn't be at this level, because a KeyError is not obviously a thing those functions should generate (bet their comments don't say that or why they generate it).

It's happening when the securitygroupwatcher thread is trying to set or remove ACLs on lines 2739 & 2749. If the iface_idx in VPP is deleted by the portwatcher thread just before the securitygroupwatcher tries to set or remove the ACL on that interface, a key error is generated. I saw this error a couple of times when running tempest.

You're right. It's happening at 2724. I was able to reproduce the issue.
Will push an updated patch shortly

specs/victoria/ansible-logging-tripleocl.message: relies

I would like us to list a list of requirements and conditions of satisfaction.

To start:
* The solution must not increase deployment and day 2 operations time.
* The solution must leverage how we can existing tooling, if possible maintained by active community.
* The solution must be simple and maintainable without too much expertise.
hmmm some of those are answered in the next parts about "impacts".. ? I'll add some more considerations about your questions so that it makes things clearer.

I think we'd have to consider ARA as an alternative here.  There has been some background conversations about improving the usability of the ansible logs via ARA.  There are technical reasons why we shouldn't use ARA however it's worth mentioning and reviewing those as part of this spec.
Getting the full alternatives is indeed good - I'll add ARA details and why, imho, it doesn't check all the needs. And I've added this spec as a topic for the next PTG.

Sure.

It looks like you've /already/ developed something that overlaps with ARA so I feel having this kind of discussion now might be a little bit backwards.

To Wes' point, specs are an exercise at evaluating needs and considering available options. It's a good idea, even if just for the sake of discussion, to document available options and why another approach might be preferable.

Hello David,
Thank you for jumping in, it's always good to get inputs :).
So, if I understand correctly, ARA is basically a new service. I'm not 100% sure tripleo users want yet another service on the undercloud, with the need of an httpd service being configured to actually see the runs and stats.

As Mathieu explained, we already have what we really want within the VF - a simple callback, plain json files, and libs that actually allow to manipulate them through the CLI, without any new service nor requirement.
More over, tripleoclient already depends on the VF base code, meaning we already have everything on the node without new needs - making the integration "easy".

Also, with the new VF dedicated CLI (openstack tripleo validator *) we introduced commands that allow to list/show history and runs content, a thing that was mandatory in the core of the validation framework.

I would rather avoid to push yet another dependency on the nodes, yet another service, yet another httpd config and so on. Since the UI has been deprecated on the Undercloud, there is no real reason to get a new GUI just for the logging management.

Ah, also: having plain json files also allows to work nicely with SOSReport and interface with other tools aiming at customer support - while also allowing to push content to some ELK if an operator wants so.

What I propose is to add mention of ARA with the pros|cons as you and me exposed them, and we'll see the outcome.

Would that be OK?

Hey David,

Thank you for the input. I wasn't aware that you were the creator of ARA.. congrats :)
Just to bring you more context around this spec. We have the validations framework, now refactored outside of TripleO code base, and now modular enough so we can import and use it as a library.
The VF, implements a callback plugin (like probably ARA does), which decrease the verbosity of Ansible, log in the ansible output and execution on the disk in a specific format, give a way to watch, interact with those logs and it also implement an ansible-runner wrapper.

I think the goal here, is to use and share this code with TripleO, so we can maintain the needs in one place, use the same mechanism as VF for logging Ansible artificat, ansible log and trace executions.

All the code is already in place, the callback, the framework, and serv the tripleo validations project for now... It just need a PoC to see what would be the TripleO specifics.

So ARA sounds close to what is proposed here, but storing logs in databases, using a Rest Api might be probably too much layers and complexity to cover this need describe in this spec.

It's just my two cents here... I let Cedric, Wes and other folks to do their own thinks :)
do you have any links for those discussions I can use to educate myself and link in here?

Hi Cedric, I'm the author of ARA.

I don't know about specific discussions (much less have links to them) but from reading this spec, I can tell that ARA could be helpful and should be considered.

I concede that there might be shortcomings or improvement opportunities in ARA but I would be more than happy to collaborate with you to make it better so we don't end up creating and maintaining a new tool.

You might already be familiar with the existing implementation of ARA 0.x in TripleO and Zuul. It uses an Ansible callback plugin to save data to a local sqlite database and then provides a web reporting interface on top of that database.

We're up to ARA 1.4 now. The mechanism is largely the same [1] but everything now sits on top of an API which (hopefully) makes it easier to integrate playbook reporting.

The API server doesn't need to run if recording data locally: ARA takes care of spinning up an ephemeral server in the background for the duration of the playbook.
If need be, you can spin up a persistent API server hooked up to MySQL or PostgreSQL to aggregate data from multiple locations like on the live demo [2].

It provides python API clients [3], is packaged for Fedora [4] and is in the process of being packaged in the CentOS configuration management SIG [5].

Let me know if you have any questions and feel free to join #ara on freenode :)

[1]: https://ara.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq.html#how-does-ara-record-data-from-ansible
[2]: https://api.demo.recordsansible.org/
[3]: https://ara.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api-usage.html
[4]: https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=24394
[5]: https://github.com/ansible-community/ara/issues/122
David, if you have some other ideas/facts you want to point, please, let me know!
I'm uncertain if logging to ansible.log in the home dir is appropriate. I wonder if it would be more beneficial to output the full logs via rsyslog for full review later but leave the stdout as is.
well, this is what is done right now for at least some parts of the commands. The goal is to change that.
I would also like to see some improvements in UX to convey that something is still running and not hung. Additionally improving timings output to the cli would be beneficial.
well... yes? direct feedback is the "something is still running".. ?

Any changes to ansible callbacks/plugins/etc can have unintended performance problems (or improvements). I think the goal would be to actually improve the responsiveness and UX for the existing stdout for cli executions.
UX is the goal here - responsiveness is something we can't ensure before at least testing. This is covered in the spec....
Why is validations-libs specified here?  I'm not certain what is needed for this effort.
because the existing code is within validations-libs, used in the validation framework, which is already a dependency of tripleoclient. CF the "Introduction" - all is explained.
Why is the call back in tripleoclient? Seems like something that should be in tripleo-ansible but enabled in the ansible.cfg config code.
right for that - will update.
maybe we can solve access with ACLs?
maybe - not sure if we actually use ACLs within tripleo. Might be interesting to investigate.

I can actually see the access list needed to review logs being several users: execution, audit, and root. We may not want to limit what we can do upfront because there's no way we're going to get security and access requirements correct for all consumers.
hmm ok. So this would indeed point to some ACLs applied to the files/directory.

I think we need to make sure the user is not hard coded to "stack". While its usually "stack" in our documentation, many deployments do not have the stack user. The actual requirement for executing tripleoclient is a non-root user with sudo "NOPASSWD" capabilities.

Using ACLs might indeed be a good solution in order to avoid some wild guessing and related things. Lemme dig a bit in t-h-t to see if we already have ACLs, and see how we might leverage them. I'll then push an update to reflect this possibility.

if we enable this logging format by default, maybe we force our use of ansible-runner to always use our callback, unless configured not to? I can see folks wanting to see the live ansible stream when debug is enabled, or something similar.
I'll replace "must" by "should" and add a work item about the possibility to override the callback at will.
we can probably get rid of this?

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/kuber.message: How is this going to work on an upgrade to stx.4.0? At what point will the new SRIOV device plugin get activated? Will this code fail before that happens?

Thanks for the great explanation Steve. We're breaking new ground here - this is the first case I am aware of where we have a new container image that depends on a change to a platform file. Some thoughts:
- Don should comment on your assumptions about when the new image will be used.
- Assuming the new image can be used on a non-upgraded worker (e.g. if pods are being moved between workers due to taking them out of service for an upgrade, would one option be to put the 'isRdma' in both locations in the config file to make either image happy? That would require a change to stx.3.0 so the unupgraded worker hosts had the updated config I guess.

Thanks Bart,

The summary is that I think there may be an issue if a user launches a _new_ pod that uses Mellanox devices with DPDK in the middle of an upgrade (after controllers are upgraded, before workers are upgraded).  The code here will not fail per-se, as it's just writing a config file. However, unexpected behaviour in any newly launched (user) container may be seen.

I'm a bit unsure of how the upgrades work wrt. upgrading the platform images.  I will start with my assumptions but please correct me if I'm wrong here:

- User decides to upgrade from say stx 3.0 -> stx 4.0.  They have currently running SR-IOV device plugin containers on the worker(s).

- I will assume that during/after the controllers have been upgraded, any new platform images are pulled into the local registry and the bringup_kubemaster playbook is executed.  In this case, the playbook will write and apply the /etc/kubernetes/sriovdp-daemonset.yaml file. 

- After the SR-IOV device plugin daemonset is applied with the new image, the currently running device plugin containers on the (non) upgraded workers will be re-started with the new image.

- However, since the workers have not been upgraded yet, they will still have an stx-3.0 version of the /etc/pcidp/config.json file which has the 'isRdma' in the wrong location for the currently running device plugin image.

Result:

- Any user containers running before the upgrade on the (non)upgraded workers that used the device plugin w/ Mellanox devices would not be affected.
- Any _new_ user containers that get launched before the workers are upgraded will likely have a problem if they intend to use DPDK with Mellanox devices.  The symptom would be an issue starting the DPDK application in the container.

Are you aware of any similar 'mid-upgrade' scenarios similar to this that have had to be dealt with?

Thanks again

I'd add another alternative - buildah connection plugin of Ansible.
It's not so featureful as ansible-bender, but it has more advantages:
1) It's part of Ansible, so no problem with downstream.
2) From 2.10 it's in ansible podman collection: https://github.com/containers/ansible-podman-collections and under our control, also it will be still part of Ansible Community Distribution, so again no problem with downstream.
3) It's very simple to use, for example creating an image with tripleo inside: https://gist.github.com/sshnaidm/b0b1781b663831dd6035a16209e8a760

Current issues with it:
1) Doesn't work well with rootless because can't mount overlayfs (exactly as podman can't). It's in progress of fixing, so I hope it will work soon with rootless w/o problems.
2) May require automation around it.
